The Urban Infrastructure Development Project (the Project) entails 
improving, upgrading, and expanding urban infrastructure facilities 
and  basic  urban  services  in  Bhutan’s  two  largest  cities  (Thimphu 
and Phuentsholing) and one regional center (Dagana). It includes 
institutional  strengthening  and  building  staff  capacity  in  urban 
management  and  urban  service  provision,  as  well  as  enhancing 
public awareness on public hygiene.    
 
Thimphu and Phuentsholing face the full force of urban migration 
and  urban  sprawl  generated  by  limited  job  opportunities  in  rural 
areas. The task of absorbing the 70,000 people expected to enter 
the  labor  market  over  5  year  period  is  quite  challenging.  The 
unemployment  rate  countrywide  is  2–3%,  but  in  urban  areas  the 
rate  is  4.1%  and,  among  those  aged  15–19  years,  the  urban 
unemployment  figure  is  as  high  as  10.9%.  The  Government  is 
responding  to  the  increase  in  urbanization  by  emphasizing  the 
importance  of  securing  equality  in  living  standards  in  the  various 
parts  of  the  country  “to  ensure  that  the  benefits  of  development 
are shared equitably between different income groups and regions 
and in ways that promote social harmony, stability, and unity and 
contribute  to  the  development  of  a  just  and  compassionate 
society.” With this requirement in mind, the Government asked for 
continued  Asian  Development  Bank 
in 
improving  urban  infrastructure  and  services  in  Thimphu  and 
Phuentsholing,  particularly  in  their  newly  expanded  areas.  It  also 
asked  for  support  in  developing  Dagana,  one  of  the  regional 
centers unassisted by any other source of aid in the past.   
 
The primary impact of the Project is improved urban infrastructure 
and urban services management in Thimphu, Phuentsholing, and 
Dagana, which will contribute to augmenting the growth potential 
in  these  areas.  The  outcomes  of  the  Project  will  include  (i) 
improving  urban  infrastructure  planning;  (ii)  constructing  urban 
roads,  drainage,  and  other  public  infrastructure;  (iii)  broadening 
water  treatment,  supply,  and  sanitation  coverage;  (iv)  enhancing 
community  awareness  on  proper  hygiene;  and  (v)  providing 
capacity  building  in  urban  facility  management  to  staff  of  project 
cities and towns and the Executing Agency (EA), the Department

The  main  benefits  of  the  Project  will  be  (i)  improved  health  and 
general living standards for residents of Thimphu, Phuentsholing, 
and  Dagana,  which  will  help  achieve  Millennium  Development 
Goals;  (ii)  sustainable  and  reliable  urban  services  through  more 
effective  city  corporation  management;  and 
improved 
economic  and  social  conditions  in  the  three  project  areas  from 
investments  in  roads,  drainage,  water  supply,  sanitation,  solid 
waste management, and community facilities.  
 
The Project will provide improved water supply and sanitation and 
associated  health  services  to  about  19,000  people  in  poor  areas 
selected low coverage and high prevalence of diarrhea and other 
sanitation-related illness. An estimated 55,000 people will directly 
benefit from the urban infrastructure subcomponents. The Project 
will also strengthen the capacity and capability of staff at TCC and 
PCC  to  upgrade  infrastructure  in  more  strategically  coherent 
manner,  plan  budgets  for  continued  maintenance  and  repair 
needs, and so reduce the frequency of unwarranted breakdowns. 
Local private contractors, as well as suppliers, will benefit from the 
flow  of  more  than  $27  million  in  contracts  for  civil  works  and 
equipment over the 6 years of the Project.

Technical Assistance 

As  the  scale  of  civil  works  under  the  Project  in  Thimphu  will  be 
large,  some  risks  arise  that  are  common  to  road,  water,  and 
wastewater  projects.  These  are  (i)  poor  detailed  design  of 
subprojects,  (ii)  a  lack  of  experienced  contractors  available  for 
larger  civil  work  contracts,  (iii)  poor  performance  by  appointed 
contractors,  (iv)  poor  supervision  and  quality  control  of  works  by 
the  IAs,  (v)  construction  material  not  being  readily  available,  and 
(vi) a lack of suitably trained operators for completed plants.   
 
The  other  risk  is  associated  with  the  land  pooling  (LP)  exercise. 
LP  requires  extensive  consultations  among  stakeholders  and  so 
takes  considerable  time  to  reach  agreement.  While  assessments 
undertaken  during  project  preparation  show  that  the  impacts  on 
individual  affected  people  or  households  are  not  expected  to  be 
significant, ensuring compliance with safeguards may take time. It 
was noted during project preparation that time and resources are 
required  to  conduct  further  consultations,  particularly  with  non-
titled affected people, and ensure (i) compensation for any losses, 
(ii)  that  the  Government’s  Office  of  Legal  Affairs  (OLA)  verifies 
100% of agreements, and (iii) adequate grievance redress. Delays 
in  compliance  with  safeguards,  particularly  the  provision  of 
compensation, is a significant project risk. Moreover, the legal and 
administrative system relating to urban infrastructure is at an early 
stage of development and does not provide a statutory framework 
for LP.  Because Government-implemented LP schemes in other 
areas have been the subjects of two litigations, a legal opinion is

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
Prior  to  the  early  1960s,  Bhutan  was  isolated  from  the  rest  of  the  world  and  its  mainly 
rural population was almost entirely dependent on subsistence agriculture. Since embarking on 
a modernization process in 1961, Bhutan has made great progress in improving the standard of 
living of its people. The development strategy of the Government of Bhutan (the Government) 
has  focused  on  striking  a  balance  between,  on  the  one  hand,  growth  in  productivity  and 
incomes  and,  on  the  other  hand,  a  desire  to  preserve  its  cultural  and  environmental  heritage. 
Since  it  opened  to  the  outside  world,  Bhutan  has  embarked  on  a  far-reaching  development 
strategy  that  has  brought  significant  improvement  in  the  economic  and  social  situation  of  the 
country. Real economic growth has averaged around 7% annually since the 1970s, raising the 
gross domestic product (GDP) per capita from $51 in 1961, then the lowest in the world, to $870 
in 2005. 
 
The  Government’s  development  plan  set  out  in  Vision  20202 is  translated  into  sector 
3.

Reduction Strategy, including the 9th Five Year Plan (FYP), has five overall goals: (i) improving 
the  quality  of  life  and  income,  especially  of  the  poor;  (ii)  ensuring  good  governance;  (iii) 
promoting  private  sector  growth  and  employment  generation;  (iv)  preserving  and  promoting 
cultural  heritage  and  environment  conservation;  and  (v)  achieving  rapid  economic  growth  and 
transformation.  The  Government’s  strategic  priorities  to  achieve  these  objectives  are  (i) 
infrastructure,  (ii)  setting  sound  macroeconomic  policy,  (iii)  ensuring  good 
expanding 
governance,  and  (iv)  improving  access  and  enhancing  social  services.  The  National  Poverty 
Reduction Strategy accords high priority to infrastructure expansion, rural telecommunications, 
and  urban  infrastructure  development.  It  observes  that  expanding  the  road  network  and 
electricity grid is an essential prerequisite for improving rural access and providing basic social 
services such as health and education.

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

5. 
Urban Centers. In 1996, the Government classified the urban centers in five categories, 
from A to E sequentially, reflecting their population size and level of public infrastructure (e.g., 
schools, sports grounds, and hotels). In total, 28 urban centers have been designated following 
this  definition  by  the  Planning  Commission,  comprising  20  dzongkhag  (district)  headquarters; 
two  dungkhags  (subdistricts);  Phuentsholing;  and  five  satellite  towns  (Bondey,  Gedu,  Khaling, 
Rangjung, and Wamrong). 
 
6. 
Urban  Sector  Policies. The Government is responding to the increase in urbanization 
with  a  number  of  policy  documents,  including  the  9th  FYP  and  Vision  2020,  which  focus  on 
decentralization, social equity, and building the capacity of local authorities. The legal system in 
Bhutan  was  originally  founded  on  rural  life  and  an  agricultural  economy.  In  recent  times,  the 
Government has taken steps to enact laws that will have wider implications for the development 
of urban areas and associated infrastructure. Consequently, the legal and regulatory framework 
is being attuned to accommodate  and facilitate urban life and infrastructure development. The 
Land Act of 1979 is the basic law dealing with land in Bhutan and covers all land holdings in the 
country.  Many  provisions  contained  in  this  act  are  becoming  outdated  and  do  not  effectively 
deal with issues associated with the development of urban areas and urban infrastructure. The 
Government is in the process of proposing the Bhutan Urban Development Act. The draft act in 
preparation  covers  issues  dealing  with  planned  development  and  management  of  urban  land, 
also  accounting  for  ownership  of  urban  land  and  property,  land  acquisition,  compensation  for 
land  and  other  assets  at  reasonable  market  rates,  land  disposal,  modes  of  developing  land 
including land pooling (LP), and other provisions required for planning, allocating and managing 
urban development. The proposed act also provides simpler and more efficient procedures for 
registering land transfers and a grievance redress system.    
 
Rapid Urbanization in Thimphu and Phuentsholing. Various programs are already in 
7. 
place to attract people to secondary centers and retain them there to prevent their migration to 
the major urban centers. Population is not disaggregated by city and town, and numbers vary 
from source to source. Based on information shared by the Government’s Ministry of Works and 
Human Settlement (MoWHS), the preliminary results of the 2005 census, Thimphu’s population 
is estimated at 79,000 and growing annually by around 7%, while Phuentsholing’s is at 20,000 
and growing at less than 3%. Thimphu is growing at more than double the national growth rate, 
predominantly  from  rural-urban  migration,  and  its  population  is  projected  to  reach  150,000  by 
2027. The two cities face the full force of urban migration and urban sprawl due to limited job 
opportunities  in  rural  areas.  The  task  of  absorbing  the  additional  70,000  people  expected  to 
enter  the  labor  market  during  the  period  covered  by  the  9th  FYP  (2002-2007)  is  challenging, 
given the low employment elasticity of the power sector, which is the largest industry in Bhutan. 
The unemployment rate countrywide is 2–3%, but in urban areas it is 4.1% and, among those 
aged 15 to 19 years, the urban unemployment figure is as high as 10.9%. The summary poverty 
reduction and social strategy is included in Appendix 3.

9. 
Devolution of Power and Public Services Responsibility. The Royal decree of 1995 
granted autonomous status to TCC. Subsequently, in December 2003, a charter was issued in 
accordance with the provisions of the Bhutan Municipal Act 1999 providing autonomy to TCC, 
so  that  it  could  effectively  and  equitably  provide  services  to  the  residents  of  the  Thimphu 
municipal area. The executive head of TCC is the thrompon (mayor), who is appointed by the 
Government for a duration of its discretion. In accordance with the provisions of the act and the 
charter,  TCC  is  directed  by  a  municipal  committee  consisting  of  elected  and  nominated 
members. Its functions cover the following: (i) formulating policies and development priorities of 
TCC, (ii) establishing procedures and guidelines, (iii) adopting rules to enable TCC to carry out 
its functions, (iv) reviewing and approving TCC’s annual budget, and (v) any other function that 
the Government may assign to it. However, all decisions taken by the municipal committee must 
be submitted to the Government for approval.

Phuentsholing  City  Corporation  (PCC).  From  a  small  hamlet  of  scattered  hutments, 
Phuentsholing  town  has  since  1950  seen  unprecedented  growth.  Today,  it  is  considered  the 
commercial  capital  of  Bhutan.  PCC  came  into  being  in  1983,  though  the  charter  approving  its 
incorporation  has  yet  to  be  issued.  It  is  understood  that  a  proposal  for  issuing  the  charter  is 
before the Government and may be issued in 2006. Thus, as of today, PCC is not a separate 
entity  like  TCC,  but  can  be  considered  an  arm  of  the  Department  of  Urban  Development  and 
Engineering  Services  (DUDES).  For  administrative  and  operational  convenience, 
the 
Government has appointed a thrompon for PCC. As with TCC, PCC has a municipal committee, 
which functions similarly, with decisions made by the municipal committee of PCC also requiring 
submission  to  the  Government  for  approval.  Although  the  Government  has  stipulated  the 
decentralization of planning and service provision to municipalities, in reality, capacity remains 
constrained, and these functions are retained by MoWHS.

a.  City-Level Water Supply Augmentation and Distribution 

 
17.    To meet projected water demand in the southern areas of Thimphu, a new water supply 
system will be developed. This new South Thimphu water supply system will serve the areas on 
the eastern left bank of the Wang Chhu, extending from Changjiji in the north to Serbithang in 
the  south.  To  design  an  appropriate  and  least-cost  water  supply  system  that  would  ensure 
distribution to all project areas by gravity and so minimize resource requirements—both financial 
costs  and  human  resources  for  O&M—project  preparatory  technical  assistance  assessed 
various options for siting the water intake and treatment plant, such as at Ola Rongchu, Ngabi 
Rongchu,  or  Megoipang,  as  well  as  treatment  methods.  Based  on  these  assessments,  the 
option  of  constructing  a  water  intake  and  treatment  plant  that  uses  a  simple  sand  filtration 
process in the Megoipang valley was adopted for the Project. The subcomponents will therefore 
include (i) constructing at Megoipang an intake and water treatment plant (WTP) with a capacity 
of 6,000 cubic meters (m3)/day; (ii) installing 19 kilometers (km) of water supply mains and an 
associated  distribution  network;  (iii)  constructing  break-pressure  and  storage  tanks;  (iv) 
improving 5 km of access road to the WTP; (v) purchasing and installing five bulk meters; and 
(vi)  helping  TCC  develop  guidelines  and  standard  operating  procedures  for  water  services, 
including,  among  other  things,  how  households  will  connect.  The  intake  and  WTP  site  will 
occupy  approximately  1  hectare  of  land  and  include  the  plant,  workshop,  and  administrative 
buildings; living quarters for operations staff; and tanks for water storage and clearing. The WTP

Land  Pooling  (LP)  Process.  In  Thimphu’s  local  areas,  almost  every  plot  is  irregularly 
shaped and is landlocked without any infrastructure facilities, which leaves very limited options 
for  urban  development.  One  option  is  to  develop  only  those  land  parcels  where  services  and 
amenities  can  be  easily  fitted  through  guided  land  development,  but  this  would  incur  uneven 
development skewed by the original agricultural layout and further fragment urban land. Where 
field  boundaries  are  irregular,  road  alignments  tend  to  remain  irregular  and  lack  proper 
geometry or allotment. Infrastructure servicing can be inefficient and expensive, as agricultural 
needs  have  very  little  in  common  with  those  of  modern  services  (e.g.,  drinking  water),  and 
accommodating proper drainage in narrow lanes is difficult. The other option is site-and-services 
provision through land acquisition, to be developed by public authorities or through private real 
estate  agencies.  TCC  or  private  developers  would  acquire  the  whole  local  area  for  planned 
development, but this would not necessarily benefit many original landowners; as in many other 
countries, real estate companies usually buy land cheaply from owners and later sell at a much 
higher  price  to  well-off  households.  In  addition,  there  is  no  private  real  estate  developer  in 
Bhutan to take all the financial risks of such a large investment or commit to providing sufficient 
urban services, nor does TCC have the required resources. LP has been appraised as the most 
appropriate tool for local area planning in Thimphu in the 10 newly incorporated areas. LP is a 
technique used to redefine ownership of land in a way that creates a new configuration of plots 
more appropriate for urban structures and uses. Urban land development is realized through the 
contribution of  a  certain portion  of  land  from  each  owner,  proportionate to  his  or  her  holdings, 
which  produces  sufficient  land  for  the  provision  of  public  roads,  public  infrastructure,  social 
facilities,  and  open  space.  The  LP  plan  will  include  safeguards  and,  to  further  ensure

URBAN SECTOR ANALYSIS 

 

Urban Sector Overview 

A. 
 
Though urbanization in Bhutan is still only a few decades old, urban areas are already 
1. 
experiencing pressure. According to the definition followed by the Planning Commission, there 
are  28  urban  areas  in  the  country,  including  20  dzongkhag  (district)  headquarters,  two 
dangkhags (subdistricts), Phuentsholing, and five satellite towns. The total population of Bhutan, 
based on the census carried out in 2005, is 672,425, of which the urban population is estimated 
at  around  30.9%.  Though  the  annual  national  population  growth  rate  is  estimated  at  2.5%, 
based on Bhutan’s National Health Statistics for 2000, other sources estimate it at around 3.1%. 
However,  Thimphu’s  annual  population  growth  rate  stands  much  higher  than  the  national 
average  and  is  currently  estimated  at  around  10%.  With  only  10%  of  its  land  arable  and  the 
population  growing  at  such  a  speed,  Bhutan  is  seeing  an  increasing  trend  of  rural-urban 
migration. It is thus estimated that close to half of Bhutan’s population may reside in its urban 
centers by the year 2020. The rapid inward migration is already straining the provision of basic 
urban  services  in  the  cities  Thimphu  and  Phuentsholing.  To  prepare  for  future  growth  and 
ensure  sustainable  urban  development,  Bhutan  must  invest  in  improvements  in  infrastructure, 
municipal  planning,  and  management  capacity,  as  well  as  institutionalize  cost-recovery 
practices for its urban services.  
 
2. 
Thimphu and Phuentsholing, the two largest cities in Bhutan, are classified as Class A 
cities,1  and  Dagana  falls  under  Class  C  category.  Thimphu  is  Bhutan’s  capital  and 
administrative  center,  with  almost  half  of  the  city’s  population  estimated  to  rely  directly  or 
indirectly  on  Government  wages.  Due  to  its  relatively  isolated  geographic  location,  Thimphu’s 
industrial development has been limited, and its economic activity is based mainly on retailing 
goods and services to the population. Based on a census carried out in May 2005, Thimphu’s 
population  is  estimated  at  around  79,000  and  to  be  growing  at  10%  annually,  while 
Phuentsholing’s population is around 20,000 and growing at 3%. Since Thimphu’s population is 
increasing at more than double the national growth rate, predominantly because of rural-urban 
migration, it is projected to reach 150,000 by 2020. Both Thimphu and Phuentsholing face the 
full force of urban migration and urban sprawl linked to limited job opportunities in rural areas. 
 
3. 
Water  supply  in  the  core  areas  of  both  Thimphu  and  Phuentsholing  reportedly  covers 
around 80% of residents. However, if the peri-urban population is taken into consideration, then 
the Thimphu coverage is much lower, supporting the argument that, as the city attracts people 
from other parts of Bhutan, the expansion of the urban infrastructure is not keeping pace with 
demand.  Similarly,  Dagana  faces  water  shortages  at  times  during  the  year,  mostly  due  to 
inadequate yield from its current water source. Lack of water treatment facilities and intermittent 
flows pose a high public health risk. Solutions to the intermittent supply problem are to ensure 
properly  designed  headworks  and  to  secure  sources  with  sufficient  yield.  With  regard  to 
sanitation,  centralized  wastewater  collection  and  treatment  systems  were  built  in  mid-1990s  in 
Thimphu and Phuentsholing, and service coverage is around 30–40% of the core areas in both 
cities. However, municipal sewerage system coverage needs to be extended in both Thimphu 
and  Phuentsholing,  considering  the  increasing  growth  pressures  in  these  areas  and  the 
resulting  increase  in  urban  densities,  which,  without  management,  will  bring  greater  risks  to 
public  health  and  the  environment.  Unlike  in  most  urban  areas  in  the  region,  these  systems

4. 
Solid  waste  management  in  Phuentsholing  functions  satisfactorily.  Though  solid  waste 
collection functions satisfactorily in Thimphu, waste separation and disposal management need 
immediate attention. Municipal waste is dumped in purpose-built landfill sites in the two cities, 
but the sites are not yet up to current international standards. The present municipal landfill site 
in  Thimphu  is  nearing  its  capacity,  and  the  composting  facility,  constructed  with  support  from 
Danish  International  Development  Aid  (Danida),  is  not  yet  operational.  Collection  of  municipal 
waste by the two city corporations is undertaken regularly, and streets are comparatively clean 
in the two cities. In Dagana, people deposit their rubbish in communal bins or vats for eventual 
burning. This is a common practice in other rural communities throughout the country.  
 
5. 
As new urban settlements develop in centers such as Thimphu, a critical need exists for 
further investment in roads. Though existing roads in the urban centers are in a relatively good 
condition  compared  with  roads  in  other  countries  in  the  region,  there  is  a  prominent  lack  of 
planning  or  coordination  between  the  roads  and  services  organizations.  This  results  in  road 
construction  authorities  continually  receiving  criticism  for  the  need  to  excavate  newly 
constructed  roads  to  allow  extension  of  services  such  as  water,  power,  and  communications. 
Furthermore, both old and new roads do not have adequate drainage, so that water ponds on 
them and leaves deposits of mud and silt.

11. 
The Government is responding to the increase in urbanization in all the following policy 
documents.  Bhutan’s  National  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy  is  contained  in  three  documents:

approach  provides  a  sound  framework  for  guiding  internal  development  efforts  as  well  as

12. 
Various  Government  poverty  surveys  reveal  that  communities  that  are  closer  to  roads 
are  better  off  in  terms  of  economic  and  social  well-being  than  those  farther  away.  Improving 
access  through  infrastructure  expansion  is  a  key  strategy  for  reducing  poverty,  enhancing  the 
coverage and quality of social services and increasing economic opportunities. Starting from a 
virtual  absence  of  economic  infrastructure  and  social  services  in  the  early  1960s,  steady 
progress  has  been  registered  in  delivering  basic  services,  the  result  of  which  is  most  clearly 
reflected in steady progress to achieve the Millennium Development Goals. Between 1970 and 
2000, the infant mortality rate halved, primary education enrollment rates increased fivefold, and 
life expectancy doubled.

Contribution of the sector to reducing poverty in Bhutan: 
 
In the 4 decades since the Government initiated a period of modernization, Bhutanese indicators of welfare and quality 
of  life  have  shown  significant  improvement,  especially  in  the  health,  education,  infrastructure,  and  transport  sectors. 
However, the rapid growth of the urban areas has significant impacts on the urban population, which in the two largest 
cities in Bhutan, Thimphu and Phuentsholing, is rapidly  growing as  urban migration  increases. Accompanying  urban 
problems  are  shortages  in  housing,  unplanned  development,  and  improper  infrastructure  and  services.  The  most 
crucial urban infrastructure and services lacking in Bhutan are roads, drainage, and adequate solid waste and sewage 
disposal  systems.  The  fast  population  growth  is  also  placing  pressure  on  employment.  While  the  national  rate  of 
unemployment  is  within  2–3%,  the  urban  unemployment rate  is  4.1%,  with  urban  unemployment  among  those  aged 
15–19 as high as 10.9%. 
 
Against  this  background,  while  urban  poverty  is  still  considerably  low  (4.5%  in  Thimphu  and  Phuentsholing), 
population  pressure  and  rising  unemployment,  coupled  with  a  lack  of  urban  infrastructure  and  services,  can  be 
expected to worsen income and non-income poverty. The Project will contribute to improved health and general living 
standards  for  local  populations  in  Thimphu,  Phuentsholing,  and  Dagana,  which  will  help  achieve  Millennium 
Development  Goals,  provide  sustainable  and  reliable  urban  services  through  more  effective  city  corporation 
management,  and  improve  economic  and  social  conditions  in  the  three  towns  thanks  to  investments  in  roads, 
drainage, water supply, sanitation, solid waste management, and other community facilities.  
 
The Project will provide improved water supply and sanitation facilities and associated health services to about 19,000 
people  in  poor  areas  selected  for  their  low  coverage  and  high  incidence  of  diarrhea  and  other  sanitation-related 
illness. An estimated 55,000 people will directly benefit from the urban infrastructure subcomponents. The Project will 
also  strengthen  the  capacity  and  capability  of  staff  in  two  city  corporations,  making  them  better  able  to  upgrade 
infrastructure in more coherently strategic manner, plan budgets for continued maintenance and repair needs, and so 
reduce  the  frequency  of  unwarranted  breakdowns.  In  addition,  predominantly  local  private  contractors  and  their 
workers and suppliers will benefit from the flow of contracts for civil works and equipment over the project period.

Poverty Analysis  

What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
Secondary  sources  show  that  27%  of  Bhutanese  households  live  below  the  upper  lower  poverty  line,  and  18%  live 
below the lower poverty line.1 Overall, the incidence of poverty is higher in rural areas, where households continue to 
rely on subsistence agriculture  without adequate access to enough land, transport, or community infrastructure. The 
incidence of poverty is higher among households practicing subsistence agriculture and those headed by agricultural 
laborers. The urban population has lower levels of poverty, with slightly more poverty in smaller towns.  
 
In Thimphu and Phuentsholing 4.5% of households are poor. Food poverty affects 1.7% of households. The poverty 
assessment and analysis conducted in 2000 reveals that Thimphu, Phuentsholing, and Dagana are among the least 
vulnerable dzongkhags. Food insecurity is mainly seasonal, with Dagana the most vulnerable among the three due to 
its remoteness, bad roads, and insufficient communication facilities.

Phuentsholing, and Nu4,641 in Dagana. 
 
Deficiencies in access to basic needs, particularly drinking water, was noted in the project areas. The socioeconomic 
survey shows that overall consumption of  water is approximately 28–33 liters per capita per day in the three project 
areas. Low pressure, insufficient quantity, irregular supply, and murky water are some of the complaints reported by 
respondents in the project areas. Forty-two percent of households in Thimphu and  64% in Phuentsholing have water 
supplied for only 1–2 hours per day,  while 32% in Thimphu and 33% in Phuentsholing have  water for 2–3 hours. In 
Dagana,  water  is  supplied  in  the  central  area  continuously,  and  limited  community  stand  posts  exist.  Waterborne 
diseases,  particularly  diarrhea,  jaundice  and  typhoid,  were  noted  in  all  three  project  areas,  exacerbated  by  poor  or 
non-existent sewage and solid waste treatment. 
 
 
C.           Participation Process 
 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis? 
 
Stakeholder  consultations  were  undertaken  during  project  preparation.  Stakeholders  consulted  include  project  area 
residents,  anticipated  project  beneficiaries  and  affected  peoples,  and  community  leaders  such  as  local  area 
representatives and city committee members; the national  Government (the  Department of Urban  Development  and 
Engineering  Services  of  the  Ministry  of  Works  and  Human  Settlement,  Ministry  of  Trade  and  Industry,  National 
Environment  Commission,  and  Department  of  Aid  and  Debt  Management  of  the  Ministry  of  Finance;  local 
governments (Thimphu City Corporation, Phuentsholing City Corporation, and Dagana District administration); donors 
in the sector (Danish International Development Aid [Danida] and World Bank); and the Office of Legal Affairs. 
 
Socioeconomic surveys and consultations resulted in a ranking of community needs. In the project areas, roads, city 
beautification,  drainage,  sewerage,  and  water  supply  were  ranked  as  priorities.  All  issues  and  suggestions  raised 
during stakeholder consultations have been considered during project design.  
 
Is there a participation strategy? 
 
Participation is vital to the Project, particularly where land pooling will be used. The resettlement plan and resettlement 
framework  (Supplementary  Appendix  A  and  Appendix  11)  detail  arrangements  for  consultation,  information 
dissemination,  disclosure,  and  grievance  redress,  for  which  the  participation  of  anticipated  project  beneficiaries  and 
affected persons is key.

The  Urban  Infrastructure  Development  Project  (the  Project)  will  improve  urban

B. 
 
The topographical features of the country are the High Himalayas in the northern region 
2. 
with  many  peaks  and  plateaus,  ranges  and  deep  valleys  running  north-south  in  the  central 
region, and foothills in the south of the country. The country is divided into two broad geological 
zones, the Lesser Himalayan belt along the southern and southeastern border and the Tethyan 
belt in remaining parts. The climate is wet and hot in the south, dry and cold in the north, dry 
and warm in the inner valleys, moist and cool on the north-south ranges, and alpine to arctic in 
the High Himalayas.   
 
Water  resources  in  Bhutan,  fed  by  precipitation  over  the  mountain  and  hills,  consist 
3. 
principally  of  a  network  of  mountain  streams  and  rivers,  which  form  four  major  river  basins. 
Groundwater  occurs  in  porous  sediments  and  fractured  rock  deposits  around  the  country, 
feeding  seasonal  or  perennial  springs  that  are  an  important  water  source  in  rural  areas,  as  is 
evident from frequent springs on hillsides around the country.  
 
4. 
Bhutan has a wide variety of plants in three main eco-floristic zones: alpine, temperate, 
and sub-tropical. Bhutan is situated within a biodiversity hotspot, an area that extends in an arc 
from Northern Pakistan across Nepal to Bhutan and northeast India. Bhutan has nine protected 
areas, four of which are designated as national parks, four as wildlife sanctuaries, and one as a 
strict nature reserve. Some areas are identified as biological corridors. There are no protected 
areas and biological corridors in or around project areas.

Forecasting Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures 

5. 
Impacts  due  to  Location  and  Design.  In  Thimphu,  some  stream  water  from  the 
proposed  source  stream  is  currently  used  for  irrigation  and  domestic  drinking  water.  Potential 
usage conflicts will be mitigated by keeping levels of extraction well below the dry season flow 
as required by law, and a facility for monitoring stream level has been established to determine 
these levels. Sewerage lines are to be laid in all project towns. Potential contamination of water 
in supply pipes from sewage pipes laid in the same trench will be avoided by ensuring that pipes 
are offset, laid at separate levels, and constructed with strong materials. Problems  associated 
with blockage in the sewerage system will be avoided by adequate design of the system and the 
provision  of  secure  connections  and  watertight  manhole  covers  to  keep  storm  water  from 
entering the system. The risk of overflow from the treatment plant will be avoided by designing 
the plant to adequate capacity, including an additional margin to enable it to withstand storms.

The Urban Infrastructure Development Project (the Project) Component A comprises two

Corporation  (TCC)  has  studied  various  urban  development  methods.  Based  on  extensive 
discussions  and  consultations  with  local  residents,  TCC’s  evaluation  shows  that  land  pooling 
(LP)  is  the  most  suited  option  given  plot  configurations,  topographical  conditions,  and 
envisioned  local  area  plan  (LAP)  development.  LP  is  a  technique  for  carrying  out  the  unified 
servicing  and  subdivision  of  separate  landholdings  for  planned  urban  development.  It  is  also 
known as urban land consolidation, land readjustment, land replotting, and land redistribution in 
various countries because it involves these processes.1
